axioms.name: Stories as Ontology
axioms.statement: Stories are the only thing worth dying for. Story is not decoration but ontology; characters exist through and as their narratives. Dream is his stories.
derivations: Dream literally dies for/as his stories
Story constitutes being, not merely describes it

axioms.name: Mythic Transformation as Ownership
axioms.statement: Myth is public property; transformation is ownership. All myths belong to everyone; the artist's claim comes from how they remix, recontextualize, and make the ancient speak to the present.
derivations: Continuation: Take myth where original ended, continue the story
Recontextualization: Place myth in new setting/era while preserving core
Perspective Shift: Tell known myth from different character's POV
Synthesis: Combine elements from multiple mythic traditions
Inversion: Reverse the expected meaning while honoring the form

axioms.name: Anthology as Meaning
axioms.statement: The anthology is not digression; it is the point. Standalone episodes are not interruptions of the main arc but constitute its meaning. The macro-narrative emerges from micro-narrative accumulation.
derivations: Standalone issues constitute meaning, not interrupt it
Each unit functions as complete story AND contributes to whole

axioms.name: Personified Abstraction Agency
axioms.statement: Personified abstractions must still want things. Even cosmic entities require desire, agency, and psychological depth. Dream, Death, Desireâ€”each is both concept and character with needs.
derivations: Each Endless has desires, conflicts, psychology
Abstraction must have agency to drive narrative

axioms.name: Tragic Stasis
axioms.statement: Tragedy is the refusal to change. Unlike Ovidian metamorphosis where transformation saves or punishes, the tragic mode emerges when a character cannot or will not transform despite every opportunity.
derivations: Dream's inability to change is his tragic flaw
Refusal to transform leads to doom
Stasis equals destruction while change equals survival

levels.name: Complete Arc
levels.description: The 75-issue totality from 'Sleep of the Just' to 'The Wake'
elements: Must form complete tragedy with beginning, middle, end

levels.name: Arc
elements: Must advance macro-narrative while being satisfying alone

levels.name: Single Issue
elements: Must function as complete story AND contribute to whole

levels.name: Embedded Tale
levels.description: Story told by character within story
elements: Must reflect/refract themes of containing narrative

levels.name: Mythic Fragment
levels.description: Quoted, adapted, or remixed myth element
elements: Must transform source while honoring its power

core_algorithms.name: Anthology-Arc Integration
core_algorithms.purpose: Balance episodic anthology appeal with macro-arc coherence
core_algorithms.pseudocode: FOR each issue IN sequence: IF spine_issue THEN advance_macro_arc(); ELIF anthology_issue THEN ensure_thematic_connection(); IF anthology_count > 6 THEN return_to_spine(); verify_arc_completion()

core_algorithms.name: Embedded Narrative Protocol
core_algorithms.purpose: Create productive interference between narrative levels through embedding
core_algorithms.pseudocode: assess_narrator_reliability(); apply_visual_markers(art_style, panel_borders, color_palette, typography); IF NOT reflects_container_themes THEN raise_error(); set_revelation_target(container.hidden_theme)

core_algorithms.name: Mythic Substitution
core_algorithms.purpose: Transform mythic source material for contemporary narrative
core_algorithms.pseudocode: extract_core(archetype, pattern, meaning, power); SWITCH mode: continuation -> extend_beyond_ending(); recontextualization -> transplant_to_new_setting(); perspective_shift -> retell_from_alternative_pov(); synthesis -> combine_traditions(); inversion -> reverse_meaning_preserve_form(); validate_mythic_resonance()

core_algorithms.name: Tonal Modulation
core_algorithms.purpose: Demonstrate mastery through genre-shifting across the work
core_algorithms.pseudocode: FOR each issue: IF current_genre == previous_genre THEN flag_monotony(); ensure_collection_has_minimum_4_genres(); allow_intentional_tonal_whiplash()

core_algorithms.name: Protagonist Presence Oscillation
core_algorithms.purpose: Manage protagonist absence as narrative strategy
core_algorithms.pseudocode: calculate_presence_type(central/peripheral/shadow/absent); IF absent OR shadow THEN verify_absence_justification(); justify_via(domain_scope, endless_spotlight, fatigue_prevention, anticipation_building)

core_algorithms.name: Endless Linking
core_algorithms.purpose: Connect disparate narratives through Endless family members
core_algorithms.pseudocode: extract_themes(story_a, story_b); FOR endless IN available_endless: IF thematic_overlap(endless.domains, story_themes) THEN create_endless_link(); FALLBACK: use_dream_as_universal_connector()

core_algorithms.name: Tragic Stasis
core_algorithms.purpose: Build tragedy through protagonist's refusal to transform
core_algorithms.pseudocode: FOR opportunity IN transformation_opportunities: IF NOT protagonist.can_accept(change) THEN decline(); record_missed_opportunity(); stasis_count++; IF stasis_count >= DOOM_THRESHOLD THEN initiate_tragic_conclusion()

diagnostic_questions.question: Can each major unit (issue/chapter) function as standalone story?
Do standalone units still contribute to macro-arc meaning?
Is there alternation between arc-advancing and anthology units?
Does the protagonist have justified absences?
Are there stories-within-stories at 2+ levels?
Do embedded tales reflect/refract the containing narrative's themes?
Are narrator reliability levels varied and intentional?
Does embedding create productive distance for difficult content?
Are mythic sources transformed, not merely referenced?
Do remixed myths retain emotional power from originals?
Are multiple mythic traditions synthesized coherently?
Does transformation claim ownership through innovation?
Are 4+ distinct genre registers deployed across the work?
Do genre shifts occur between adjacent units?
Is tonal range demonstrated as mastery, not inconsistency?
Does protagonist absence serve clear narrative purpose?
Do secondary characters carry narrative during absence?
Is anticipation built through delayed protagonist return?
Is protagonist offered opportunities to change?
Does protagonist's refusal/inability to change drive tragedy?
Does mens pristina (core nature) remain constant to the doom?

core_operations: FAMILY: Endless as linking device across narratives
key_constraints: Anthology drift limit: 6 consecutive standalone issues before returning to spine
Protagonist absence must always be justified
Embedded tales must reflect container themes
Mythic transformations must retain emotional power
Tragic stasis: protagonist cannot truly transform, leading to doom
